rComments: Took a mandatory Indigenous course at St Paul Uni. I don't think white ppl r oppressed but she made a point of grading white students extremely hard. I have never felt more anxious than I did in this classroom. She created such a nasty, traumatic, spiteful environment. She let her radical opinions permeate the content. She shouldn't be an educator

This class was mandatory. There is no other prof I can take to do this class. Tracy made people cry, literally. On top of it, she made people cry in front of the class. It was difficult to see how innocent students, from all over the world, developed the guilt for centuries old colonization of Canada. Be ready.

I've had Tracy twice now and had very mixed feelings at first. After my second course I began to realize how much she truly cares and how passionate she is for the subject. She is there to tell the truth and inspire. Attend office hours, join her Facebook groups, ask questions and you will realize how intelligent and inspiring she truly is.

One of the best classes I have taken in undergrad! Professor Coates is an incredible teacher in- and outside of the classroom. As a non-Indigenous student she has opened my eyes to Aboriginal teachings. She goes above and beyond for her students - our assessments included going on field trips, working with a local NGO and creating our own stories.

I am a leftist at heart, but this is a whole new level. If you are white and catholic, be prepared to leave class feeling constantly guilty and awful for being of a race which, as history shows, has been awful. She has no regard for modern day realities. Would have all non-Indigenous people go back to Europe. And pushes her agenda onto her pupils.

LITERALLY THE BEST PROFESSOR I HAD. She is so so passionate about what she teaches, and teaches it in different ways to keep you engaged. You do have to go to class to get the notes, but she makes going to class soooooo much fun. definitely recommend!!

Incredible prof. If you came to university to *learn*, rather than tick boxes and get a B average to get a menial desk job, this should be a mandatory course. The knowledge you receive goes beyond the course, it forces you to challenge your views of the world, and yourself.

AMAZING TEACHER This woman is so kind and understanding. As long as you send her an email explaining the (valid) situation, you will get a break. She is awesome, always helpful and there for her students. Yes you have a lot of projects to do, but it makes up for no midterms or exams. Easy class as long as you work for it & love what you're studying

If you want to be taught that everything that is wrong in our society leads back to Western culture then take this class. If you want to be taught how we should adapt to an aboriginal way of life instead of western culture take this class. Tracy will push her leftist agenda and will ask you to blame all your problems on western society.

Tracy is a wonderful prof. She cares about her students & their learning, and is always ready to answer any questions you might have. This is definitely not a light-on-the-reading course but the readings are usually pertinent and interesting, and while the midterm was multiple choice, all of the topics on it had definitely been previously covered.
teacherRatingTags: ['Caring', 'Graded by few things', 'Get ready to read']

rComments: Tracy Coates has a very interesting way of teaching. I have learnt a lot through the way in which she teaches. She often has us go over her teaching in groups in order to ensure we are learning from one another rather than just her. Learning the things in which she teaches from a women that is Indigenous herself makes it much better overall.

Although she does share this class with another professor, she gives good explanation for the topics that she is explaining. She's not rude, she likes to form people into groups to help them gain knowledge from the people around you to expand your own knowledge. She does bring down the Western society, but she has her own reasoning towards why.

She shares this class with Claudette Commanda, who is an amazing lecturer. Professor Coates, not so much. She boasts about her style of Indigenous pedagogy and has ended up teaching the class nothing concrete about Aboriginal culture. She makes us get into groups multiple throughout the lecture to talk about nothing. I've learned nothing from her.
she taught intro to aboriginal studies. Shared it with another prof. Exams multiple choice and somewhat unfair. Not clear grading criteria. She somewhat rants in her lectures.

This was my favourite class of my entire degree. The Prof really wants you to succeed, and will go out of her way to help you understand the topics.   If you go into class with a willingness to learn and participate, you will do well.

Professor Coates is an amazing professor.  Her pedagogy is entirely Indigenous, something which is lacking greatly at uOttawa (so unlike boring lecture classes).   As this is a research methods class, the entire group project produces actual research, not just some essay that gets read once! Because of her methods, you can't help but learn!
assignments unorganized, weird guest lecturers (un-related to course content), did not learn what I expected to
teacherRatingTags: ['Participation matters', 'Get ready to read', 'Lots of homework']

rComments: Tracy is a creative professor. She provides a variety of assignments. For our class, we were able to create virtual timelines, videos and essay frameworks. Her feedback on assignments is clear. She is open to discussing the course and assignments both inside and outside of class. Would definitely take again.

Great prof. Really knows what she's talking about and focuses on an Aboriginal pedagogy instead of the traditional teaching methods. It's a bit off throwing at first, but after a few classes you get into the swing of things. Show up, participate, get to know her, have fun. Would definitely take her class again.
